result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Routed to Greta P for completion -Tyler S 9/28/2022

10:12 AM Defendant BRIAN A ROMASHKO in court.  Attorney Emma K Blankschein in court for BRIAN A ROMASHKO.  Prosecuting attorney Amanda Nash in court for the State of Wisconsin. Case was set for ARNG today. Notes on the case state that the Court Commissioner did not find probable cause for hit and run - involve great bodily harm.  The information that was filed states hit and run - involve great bodily harm.  The State requests to adjourn to look into this.  Defense doesn't object, but requests the DE be allowed to appear via zoom.  The Court will require the DE to appear in person. Victim addresses the court.Bond Continues.
Arraignment scheduled for November 28, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Stipulation on Discovery Possession and Dissemination

10:02 AM Defendant BRIAN A ROMASHKO in court.  Attorney Emma K Blankschein in court for BRIAN A ROMASHKO.  Prosecuting attorney Amanda Lynn Folger in court for the State of Wisconsin. Testimony taken. Court does not find probable cause for great bodily harm. Court amends complaint to Hit and Run. State requests amendment to Felony Hit and Run-Injury. Court amends to Felony Hit and Run-Injury. The Court did confirm with the State that they are in compliance with Marsy's Law. Victim addresses the court. Record closed @ 1033
Arraignment scheduled for September 26, 2022 at 10:00 am.
